The Richter scale for earthquakes is an example.
A mechanical analog computer.
Used for multiplication and division before calculators.
A tool with sliding scales.
A method of proof used to establish that a given statement is true for all natural numbers.
Involves a base case and an inductive step.
A special type of proof.
A collection of distinct objects.
The foundation of mathematics.
Written with curly braces.
A member of a set.
The individual objects within a collection.
In the set {1, 2, 3}, 2 is an ____.
A set that has a limited number of elements.
A set whose elements can be counted.
The set of numbers from 1 to 10.
A set that has an unlimited number of elements.
Example: the set of all integers.
Cannot be counted.
The number of elements in a set.
The size of a set.
The ____ of the set {1, 2, 3} is 3.
The set of all subsets of a given set.
If a set has n elements, its power set has 2^n elements.
Example: the power set of {a, b} is {{}, {a}, {b}, {a,b}}.
An operation on two sets.
Produces a set of all ordered pairs where the first element is from the first set and the second is from the second.
A diagram that uses circles to show the relationships between sets.
Used to illustrate union and intersection.
Named after a British logician.
A factor of a number that is also a prime number.
Used in prime factorization.
Example: 2 and 3 are the prime factors of 12.
A factor of a number that is a composite number.
Example: 4 and 6 are composite factors of 12.
The opposite of a prime factor.
A number with exactly two factors, 1 and itself.
Examples are 2, 3, 5, 7.
The building blocks of integers.
A number with more than two factors.
Examples are 4, 6, 8, 9.
Can be broken down into prime factors.
Two integers are ____ if their only common positive divisor is 1.
Also known as relatively prime.
Example: 7 and 10.
A system of arithmetic for integers.
Involves remainders.
Often used with clock time.
A pattern of increase where a quantity grows at a rate proportional to its current value.
Looks like a J-curve on a graph.
Faster than linear growth.
A pattern of decrease where a quantity falls at a rate proportional to its current value.
Used to model radioactive half-life.
Gets slower as it approaches zero.
A logarithm to the base e.
Often written as 'ln'.
Used in calculus and science.
An irrational number approximately equal to 2.718.
The base of the natural logarithm.
Known as 'e'.
A fraction where the numerator is greater than or equal to the denominator.
Can be converted to a mixed number.
Example: 5/4.
A number consisting of a whole number and a fraction.
Example: 1 and 1/4.
Converted from an improper fraction.
A shared multiple of the denominators of several fractions.
Needed to add or subtract fractions.
LCM is the smallest one.
One of a pair of numbers whose product is 1.
To find the reciprocal of a fraction, flip it.
The reciprocal of 2 is 1/2.
The result of multiplying an integer by itself.
Example: 9 is a ____ number because 3x3=9.
Perfect square.
The result of multiplying an integer by itself three times.
Example: 27 is a ____ number because 3x3x3=27.
Perfect cube.
A polyhedron formed by connecting a polygonal base and a point.
Ancient structures in Egypt.
Volume is 1/3 base area times height.
A perfectly round geometrical object in three-dimensional space.
Every point on its surface is equidistant from its center.
The shape of a basketball.
A three-dimensional geometric shape that tapers smoothly from a flat circular base to a point.
An ice cream ____ is this shape.
Its volume is 1/3 pi times r squared times h.
A three-dimensional solid with two parallel circular bases.
The shape of a can of soda.
Its volume is pi times r squared times h.
A three-dimensional shape with six rectangular faces.
The shape of a box.
Its volume is length times width times height.
A prism with bases that are trapezoids.
Used in architecture and engineering.
A solid with trapezoid ends.
The longest side of a right-angled triangle.
The side opposite the right angle.
The 'c' in a^2 + b^2 = c^2.
A leg of a right triangle.
One of the two shorter sides.
Plural is 'cateti'.
A polyhedron composed of four triangular faces.
The simplest of all the convex polyhedra.
A triangular pyramid.
A polyhedron with eight faces.
Its faces are triangles.
Looks like two square pyramids joined at their bases.
A polyhedron with 20 faces.
Its faces are triangles.
One of the Platonic solids.
A polyhedron with 12 faces.
Its faces are pentagons.
One of the Platonic solids.
A three-dimensional figure formed by six parallelograms.
A prism with a parallelogram base.
A squashed box.
A geometric shape that contains self-similar patterns.
Looks the same at any level of magnification.
The Mandelbrot set is an example.
Arranged in or extending along a straight or nearly straight line.
A type of equation or function.
Relates to a straight line.
Not forming a straight line.
A type of equation or function.
Example: a parabola is a ____ function.
The property of an object or shape that is the same on both sides.
Can be rotational or bilateral.
A line down the middle of a butterfly shows this.
An operation that changes the position or size of a shape.
Includes translation, rotation, and reflection.
Moving a shape without changing it.
